question.text: The potential energy U between two atoms in a diatomic molecule as a function of the distance x between atom has been shown in the adjoining figure. The atoms are

options.text: Attracted when  <math><mi>x</mi></math>  lies between  <math><mi>A</mi><mi> </mi><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">n</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">d</mi><mi> </mi><mi>B</mi></math>  and are repelled when  <math><mi>x</mi></math>  lies between  <math><mi>B</mi><mi> </mi><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">n</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">d</mi><mi> </mi><mi>C</mi></math>

Attracted when  <math><mi>x</mi></math>  lies between  <math><mi>B</mi><mi> </mi><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">n</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">d</mi><mi> </mi><mi>C</mi></math>  and are repelled when  <math><mi>x</mi></math>  lies between  <math><mi>A</mi><mi> </mi><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">n</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">d</mi><mi> </mi><mi>B</mi></math>

solution.text: Negative value of potential energy decreases from  <math><mi>C</mi><mi> </mi><mi mathvariant="normal">t</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">o</mi><mi> </mi><mi>B</mi></math>  and there after increases. It shows that kinetic energy increases from  <math><mi>C</mi><mi> </mi><mi mathvariant="normal">t</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">o</mi><mi> </mi><mi>B</mi></math>  and there after it decreases. So, there is attraction from  <math><mi>C</mi><mi> </mi><mi mathvariant="normal">t</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">o</mi><mi> </mi><mi>B</mi></math>  and after which repulsion results.
